title: Never Ever (2016 film)
text:
Never Ever () is a 2016 mystery romance film directed by <a href="Beno%C3%AEt%20Jacquot">Benoît Jacquot</a>, starring <a href="Mathieu%20Amalric">Mathieu Amalric</a> and <a href="Julia%20Roy">Julia Roy</a>. Roy also wrote the screenplay for the film, based on <a href="Don%20DeLillo">Don DeLillo</a>'s novel "<a href="The%20Body%20Artist">The Body Artist</a>". The film had its world premiere at the <a href="73rd%20Venice%20International%20Film%20Festival">73rd Venice International Film Festival</a> on 9 September 2016.
Plot.
A performance artist Laura meets a film director Rey. The two fall in love and get married. After Rey dies of a motorcycle accident, Laura feels alone in her house.
Production.
In 2013, it was reported that <a href="Luca%20Guadagnino">Luca Guadagnino</a> would direct a film adaptation of <a href="Don%20DeLillo">Don DeLillo</a>'s novel "<a href="The%20Body%20Artist">The Body Artist</a>" and <a href="Isabelle%20Huppert">Isabelle Huppert</a>, <a href="Denis%20Lavant">Denis Lavant</a>, and <a href="David%20Cronenberg">David Cronenberg</a> would star in the film. In 2015, it was reported that <a href="Beno%C3%AEt%20Jacquot">Benoît Jacquot</a> would direct the film and <a href="Mathieu%20Amalric">Mathieu Amalric</a> and <a href="Jeanne%20Balibar">Jeanne Balibar</a> would star in the film. In that year, it was reported that Julia Roy had joined the cast. Roy also wrote the screenplay for the film. Filming took place in Portugal.
Release.
The film had its world premiere at the <a href="73rd%20Venice%20International%20Film%20Festival">73rd Venice International Film Festival</a> on 9 September 2016.
It was also screened at the <a href="2016%20Toronto%20International%20Film%20Festival">2016 Toronto International Film Festival</a> and the 29th <a href="Tokyo%20International%20Film%20Festival">Tokyo International Film Festival</a>. It was released in France on 23 November 2016.
Reception.
Guy Lodge of "<a href="Variety%20%28magazine%29">Variety</a>" called the film "an enjoyably slinky but disposable divertissement from director Benoit Jacquot that is unlikely to leave viewers quite as haunted as its characters." Neil Young of "<a href="The%20Hollywood%20Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a>" commented that "it palpably aspires to be a classily highbrow kind of romantic ghost story with psychological thriller undertones, but falls laughably short of its goals."
